routing_summary.excerpt_summary: Section 5 gives a non-normative, high-level overview of DHCPv6 client/server exchanges: basic UDP use, client multicast behavior, two-message vs four-message exchanges (stateless, Rapid Commit, Renew), and server-initiated Reconfigure.

Temporal.explanation: Discusses message sequencing only at a descriptive level; detailed normative sequencing is in Section 18 and appears consistent.

ActorDirectionality.explanation: Roles (client vs server) and who sends what are clear and align with later normative text.

Scope.explanation: Text is clearly scoped as an overview; deeper per-message rules are deferred to later sections.

Causal.explanation: Describes high-level cause/effect (e.g., Renew extends lifetimes, Reconfigure triggers client messages), but no obvious logical contradictions with the detailed procedures.

Quantitative.explanation: No critical numeric ranges or timers defined here; those are in Sections 7.6 and 15.

Deontic.explanation: Section 5 largely avoids RFC 2119 keywords; normative requirements are elsewhere, so contradictions are unlikely here.

Structural.explanation: No ABNF/YANG/diagrams beyond simple flow descriptions; nothing to cross-check structurally.

CrossRFC.explanation: References (UDP RFC, DNS/NTP options, renumbering docs) are generic context; no tight cross-RFC dependencies to verify here.

Terminology.explanation: Uses standard terms (Solicit, Advertise, Request, Reply, Renew, Rebind, Reconfigure) consistent with later sections and RFC 8415 terminology.

Boundary.explanation: Edge conditions (e.g., what if Renew fails) are explicitly deferred to Section 18; no boundary behavior is defined here that could conflict.

candidate_issues.short_label: No concrete inconsistency or underspecification in Section 5 itself
candidate_issues.sketch_for_experts: Section 5 functions as an informal overview of message patterns and points the reader to later sections (7, 14, 15, 16, 18, 21) for normative detail. The descriptions of stateless vs stateful operation, two-message Rapid Commit vs four-message exchanges, Renew/Rebind, and Reconfigure-initiated flows appear consistent with those later sections and with RFC 8415 behavior. Phrases like “two-message exchange as described earlier” are informal cross-references rather than normative hooks, so they do not create interoperability problems. No plausible error rises to the level of an erratum candidate based on this excerpt.
